title: What is a Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) attack?
content: Explain how MITM attacks work and their potential impact on web applications.
explanation: In a MITM attack, an attacker intercepts communication between a client and server, potentially stealing sensitive data like passwords, cookies, or session tokens, or modifying the communication without the user's knowledge.
sampleAnswers: In a MITM attack, an attacker intercepts communication between a client and server, potentially stealing sensitive data like passwords, cookies, or session tokens, or modifying the communication without the user's knowledge.

title: How can HTTPS prevent MITM attacks?
explanation: HTTPS encrypts communication, validates the server's certificate, and combined with Secure cookies, helps prevent MITM attacks.

options.text: Encrypts data between client and server
Prevents cookie theft if Secure flag is set

title: What is CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)?
content: Explain CORS and its role in web security.
explanation: CORS is a security feature implemented by browsers to restrict web pages from making requests to a different domain than the one that served the web page. Proper CORS headers allow safe cross-origin requests while preventing unauthorized access.
sampleAnswers: CORS is a security feature implemented by browsers to restrict web pages from making requests to a different domain than the one that served the web page. Proper CORS headers allow safe cross-origin requests while preventing unauthorized access.

title: How can you safely allow cross-origin requests?
explanation: Allow only trusted domains, use credentials carefully, and proxy requests server-side to control access. Using '*' allows any domain and is unsafe for sensitive data.

options.text: Set Access-Control-Allow-Origin to a specific trusted domain
Use server-side proxy to handle requests

title: What is rate limiting and why is it important?
content: Explain how rate limiting protects web applications.
explanation: Rate limiting restricts the number of requests a client can make in a given time period, protecting the server from abuse, brute-force attacks, and denial-of-service attacks.
sampleAnswers: Rate limiting restricts the number of requests a client can make in a given time period, protecting the server from abuse, brute-force attacks, and denial-of-service attacks.

title: True or False: All third-party libraries are safe by default.
content: Evaluate the statement in terms of frontend security.

options.explanation: Third-party libraries can have vulnerabilities, outdated dependencies, or malicious code; always review and update them.
Always validate, audit, and update third-party libraries before using them in production.

title: What is JWT and how does it help with security?
content: Explain JWT (JSON Web Token) and its use in authentication.
explanation: JWT is a compact token used to securely transmit information between client and server. It ensures authenticity and integrity of the payload, commonly used for stateless authentication.
sampleAnswers: JWT is a compact token used to securely transmit information between client and server. It ensures authenticity and integrity of the payload, commonly used for stateless authentication.

title: How can you prevent XSS when displaying user-generated content?
explanation: Escape and sanitize user content, and enforce CSP. Avoid unsanitized dangerouslySetInnerHTML as it introduces XSS vulnerabilities.

options.text: Sanitize input using libraries like DOMPurify

title: What is UI Redressing (Clickjacking)?
content: Explain how clickjacking attacks manipulate user interface elements.
explanation: Clickjacking occurs when attackers overlay a transparent or disguised element over a legitimate UI element, tricking users into clicking it and performing unintended actions like submitting forms or changing settings.
sampleAnswers: Clickjacking occurs when attackers overlay a transparent or disguised element over a legitimate UI element, tricking users into clicking it and performing unintended actions like submitting forms or changing settings.

title: How do you prevent clickjacking attacks?
explanation: X-Frame-Options and CSP frame-ancestors prevent your site from being embedded in iframes, mitigating clickjacking attacks.

options.text: Use X-Frame-Options header to deny framing
Use Content Security Policy frame-ancestors directive
Implement UI overlays as security measure
